properties.Cave_Description:
The cave of Agios Ioannis is a very well known cave, located on the southwestern part of Irakleia Island at 110m a.s.l. A 2.5 km marked path is leading from Panagia settlement to its entrance. The cave is heavily decorated with a variety of speleothems. There are two main spacious chambers measuring 170 m in total length and covering an area of 2,000 sq. m. Although it’s not officially a show cave, several hundred people are visiting it every summer. The cave is dedicated to St John the Prodrome and his memory is celebrated with vespers at the big hall of the cave every year on 28th August.
The Polydesmid milliped was cited as "Serradium or Brachydesmus" (Andreev 1986). The Lindbergia species was cited as  Lindbergia sp. aff pseudoillyrica (Riedel 1990 & 1992)

properties.Protection_Status: GR2530004 - Oros Oligyrtos (Special Area of Conservation): Law 3937/2011 (OGG/Α 60/31.03.2011), Joint Ministerial Decision 50743/2017 (OGG 4432/B/15.12.17). Check site’s Standard Data Form
properties.Cave_Description: The cave is located 1.3 km east of Kandyla village, at 1,070m a.s.l. The entrance is small (1*0.6 m). There is one main gallery 100 m in length and 0.5-6.5 m in height with several large rimstone pools.

properties.Cave_Synonyms: Loutses cave, Bodolekos cave, Höhle am Nordabhang des Pantokratorgebirges, Grotta superiore di Bodolekos, Ano Peristerograva, Peristerograva
properties.Cave_Description: Peristerograva is located 1.4 km south-east of the village of Loutses at 480m a.s.l. There is only one large and descending chamber (100m long, 40m deep and 60m high).

properties.Cave_Description: The mines of Lavrio is a huge cluster of vertical wells and horizontal man-made galleries. They have been opened in the wider area of Lavreotiki from the antiquity until 1977 when the operation of the lead mines has ceased. The depth of the wells varies from 10 m to 150 m and some are clogged or are in a hazardous condition to visit.
A small cave (20m long, 3.5 to 0.5m in height) located on a hill, 2km east from Kitsi settlement (140m a.s.l.)

properties.Cave_Synonyms: Spilaio Lordou Vyrona (Lord's Byron cave), Spilia Nymphis, Spilaio Nymfon,  Spilaio Panos
properties.Cave_Description: The cave is situated on the southern slopes of the Keratovouni Mt. (Paneio Mt.) at 600m a.s.l. (Keratea). In a length of 60m, there are 4 main chambers with a total area of 950 sq. m. The cave is decorated with various well-developed speleothems. A rimstone pool is filled with water all year round.

It is an underground river that continuously flowing in its last section. The passageways length is 600m long in total, covering an area of 1,950 sq. m.

properties.Protection_Status: Archaeological Site - Ministerial Decision 16685/532/6-4-1981 (OGG 278/Β/14-5-1981)
properties.Cave_Description: The cave is situated at 220m a.s.l., 1.2 km northwest of the Skoteino village. The entrance opens in a 25*25m doline. The first gallery of the cave is impressive (134 m long, 33 m wide and 30 m high). At the lower part, there is a smaller chamber measuring 18 x 12 m. The floor area of the cave is 2,500 sq. m. Although it’s not officially a show cave, several thousand people are visiting it every summer. The cave is dedicated to Saint Paraskevi and her memory is celebrated with a feast at the entrance of the cave every year on 26th July.

The most distant part is 170m from the entrance, the total length of the passageways is 600m and the floor covers an area of 2,700 sq. m. The maximum ceiling height is 10 m. Speleothems are rich in forms and quite developed.

properties.Cave_Description: The cave is situated 1km east of the village of Milatos on the northern cliffs of a gorge at 170m a.s.l. It is easily accessible from the main road through a 270m path. The cave has 8 entrances along a face of 40m. The total floor area is 2,100 sq. m but a small percentage is not accessed by daylight. Inside the cave, there is a small church dedicated to St Thomas and an ossuary, containing bones from the victims killed in the cave by ottomans in 1823. Although it’s not officially a show cave, several thousand people are visiting it every year.

properties.Cave_Description: The cave of Antiparos is situated on the southeastern side of the island W on the hill of Agios Ioannis at the height of 180m a.s.l. The cave is impressively decorated with various speleothems. The floor is quite steep and occupies an area of 5,600 sq.m. The main gallery is 70 m wide reaching a depth of 85 m lower than the entrance level the entrance and a maximum roof height of 40m. The cave has been in use since Neolithic times. It became a great attraction since the 18th century as result by several publications, printed drawings and pictures of the cave. There are several inscriptions and carvings on the speleothems, some a few centuries old. Today the cave is managed as a show cave.

properties.Cave_Description: The species Stalita cretica Roewer 1928 was erroneously reported from the cave of Agia Sophia (Topolia, Crete) by Roewer (1928). Deeleman-Reinhold (1993) examined the type species and found it indistinguishable from Stalagtia hercegovinensis which does not occur in Greece. It appears that Roewer mislabeled the specimens supposedly collected on 1926 in Crete (Beier 1931) as he has done with pseudoscorpions (Helversen & Martens 1972).

properties.Cave_Description: Korykeio Antro is the cave from where the first cave animals of Greece have been recorded. From the samples collected by Th. J. Krüper, Brunner Von Wattenwyl (1861) identified the cave cricket Rhaphidophora cavicola -a record assigned recently to Troglophilus zoia (Di Russo et al. 2014)- and Schaum (1962) described a new ground-beetle species (Anophthalmus Krueperi = Duvalius krueperi), the first obligate cave-dwelling species recorded in Greece.

properties.Cave_Description: The cave of Maronia is located 5 km west of the homonymous settlement, at the location "Koufou Plai" or "Koufoplati", on the eastern slope of Mount Ismaros. The cave is s developed in a thin layer of Eocene nummulitic limestones which have a fragmented appearance in the wider area.  The cave has two entrances. The main entrance measures 3.5*1.5m and divides the cave into two sections, a left (NE) entrance with a total length of 240m, and a right (NW) entrance with a total length of 160m. On the NE side of the northern part of the cave, there is a second entrance of smaller dimensions. The cave has an average width of 30m, an average height of 6m, a maximum depth of 20m and occupies a total area of about 1ha (Petrocheilou 1970 & 1984).

properties.Cave_Description: It is probably the cave  Kryfos Spilios. Petroceilou (1972) explored it on November 11, 1970. She reports the collection of Dolochopoda cave crickets to be studied by specialists. Kryfos Spilios is a small cave (2m wide, 15m long). It is located at Pouria, 500m a.s.l., 10km away from Stomio on the right side of the dirt road Plevna-Alataries-rema Pouri-rema Periseras.

properties.Cave_Description: A small cave that opens on the eastern slope of Mt. Vardousia at the side of the dirt road that links Athanasios Diakos to Dafni. The cave is about 20-30 m long and consists of a single room. Di Russo et al. 2014 mention another unnamed cave at Mount Vardousia (1,110m asl) where Dolichopoda lustriae was collected by P. M. Giachino and D. Vailati on 10.VI.2005. This is probably the same cave. The location and the sort description of Dafni cave provided by Alexiou et al. 2014, matches with the cave of Athanasios Diakos, described by Petrochilou 1992.

K723 - Nevrokopi, Leivadakiou, Achladias, Mikrokleisouras, Volakos, Granitou Dimou Kato Nevrokopiou [Wildlife Refuge]: OGG 639/Β/2001
properties.Cave_Description: In his notes, Weirather, reports that the cave and the chapel of Agioi Theodoroi (Peštera crkva Sv. Todore nr.322 ) are located south of the village Kolak [sic] (Giachino & Lana 2005, Pretner 2011). Probably he misspelled the name Volak (Volakas). The only well-known cave and chapel of Agioi Theodoroi are located SW of Volakas (NE of Kato Nevrokopi) at Agioi Theodoroi ridge and presumably, this is the cave nr 322. The altitude (1,000m a.s.l.) and the religious use of the cave are in line with Weirather’s notes.

properties.Cave_Synonyms: Karouba cave, Spilaio Karouba, Höhle Karouba
properties.Cave_Description: All species were collected from "Aus der Höhle Karouba, östlich von Sitia" with no other information for its location. There is no village nor a cave named "Karouba" east of Siteia (Lasithi, Crete). The only related known toponym is the Karoumes valley and its small bay 2,7 km E of Chochlakies village (15 km SE of Siteia). The name comes "Karoumes" (=Karoubes) comes from the Arabic word Karub (=Carob). Not far from the beach, on the top of a hill, there is a cave known as Spiliara Karoumon (Lat  35.145030, Lon 26.270561, 80m a.s.l.)

According to the notes of Weirather (Giachino & Lana 2005, Pretner 2011), the cave is situated on a hill above an isolated church at Madara Mt, west of Pyrgaki village.

Unknown exact location. Weirather locates this small cave at Michaliko hill of Kochylas Mt. at about 700m a.s.l.  (Giachino & Lana 2005, Pretner 2011). The name of the hill does not exist on the Skyros map of the Hellenic Military Geographical Service (HMGS). Presumably, the cave is located in the central (higher) part of Kochylas Mt.
According to Wang & Li (2011) the cave is situated near Kosmas village (Parnon Mt., Arkadia), close to the Cemetary.

properties.Cave_Description: It is located on the tip of Cape Roti (hence the name), near Psarades village. The entrance and the first part of the cave are only accessible by boat. Its length is approx. 50 m and width 3-6 m. Its height is approx. 10 m near the entrance lowering down to 3 m towards the interior of the cave.
A small cave 1,2 km west of Vourgareli. It consists of a semicircular room partially illuminated in daylight, with a diameter of about 15 m.

A cave chapel situated 12 km southwest of Dirrachi in Goupata Rachi, north of Kalamata (Reischütz & Reischütz 2003). From the site location description, we assume that it's the cave of Agioi Anargyroi. The cave is about 20 meters long. The front part is concreted and used as a chapel. The last five meters are still more or less natural. Together with the Tsoukatosia christinae n.sp.  Reischütz & Reischütz (2003) also found representatives of the genera Lindbergia, Oxychilus, and Pagodulina.
